reviewText:
BUY/SALE/PASS: Buy - Feel free to buy at full price

Divekick is a recent addition to the fighting game genre developed by Iron Galaxy Studios and released in late August.  Everyone loves fighting games, right?

No.  Not everyone.  But why?

The fact of the matter is that for most fighting games the barrier to entry is complexity.  Players must learn about each of the characters, how to perform special techniques, and master precision combinations on a six-button layout just to be able to compete.

Divekick throws all the rules out the door and introduces simple yet absurd gameplay.  The madness begins with a simple premise: there are no movement controls, and there are only two buttons: Dive and Kick.  Pressing Dive makes the player dive into the air, and pressing Kick while in the air causes the player to kick downward towards the opponent.  Pressing the Kick button while on the ground causes the player to jump backward away from the opponent.  These are the only ways to move around the arena.  All divekicks are one hit kills.  The first to five kills wins.

Not exactly what you would expect, huh?

What if I told you that it’s one of the most engrossing fighting games released in the past five years?

In a time when fighting games regularly introduce complexity, it’s refreshing to see a game that breaks fighting games down to the bare essentials; strategy.  None of the 13 characters, each of whom dive and kick differently, are severely overpowered.  There are  no long combos to memorize, no comeback super techniques.  With no complexity, all that’s left is mind games; the ability to fake out your opponent, the rush of emotion when a plan is executed and comes together flawlessly.

While Divekick is generally understood to be a parody of the fighting game genre, it also unearths concepts that have been buried under layers of complexity for too long and brings the genre back around full circle.  Divekick cannot be recommended enough for any fighting game enthusiast willing to try something nice and silly..

reviewText:
Divekick is a fighting game you won't need to spend hours in a training mode practicing combos that'll never land anyway in order to get better. You may not immediately click with its unique parody of fighting games and general poking fun at the fighting game community, but at the very least, you'll probably be pretty good at Divekick by the end of your first match due to its elegance in simplicity.

1 Dive Button.
1 Kick button.
1 hit and you're dead.
5 rounds won and you're godlike.
1 hell of a good time.

That's all you really need to know to get started playing Divekick. Jumping and kicking moves you forward and pressing the kick button while on the ground hops you backward, which can  you can also attack during. You couldn't ask for something more approachable.

Divekick's depth comes from managing the space between you and your opponent and trying to outwit one another to land that crucial winning blow. All thirteen characters have unique kick angles and characteristics that are suited for beginners (Dive and Kick) all the way up to characters that require a lot of skill and patience (S-Kill and Stream).  All special moves in the game are activated by pressing both buttons at once on the ground or in the air. It's just up to you to figure out how to best utilize them.

Multiplayer is what makes Divekick truly shine. While the AI can be good for getting to know your character a bit, the game's honestly a much better affair when paired with other players either online or locally. The implementation of GGPO keeps matches online mostly silky smooth, though the lack of a proper 4-8 player lobbies is a bit of a bummer.

Even if Divekick is targeted at folks who love their fighting games, its simplistic approach, low skill barrier for entry, and lighthearted nature make it easily recommendable and enjoyable for anyone simply looking to have a good time.

reviewText:
It’s all about that one moment. Everyone who’s ever played or watched a fighting game knows it. It’s the final round, both players have a slither of health left and the next move is pivotal; the difference between success and failure, win or lose. Whether it’s playing against a friend, competing in an online ranked match or watching one of the many tournament streams of the fighting game community, everyone knows that one moment. It’s the veritable height of tension, excitement, elation and anguish. Divekick is that one moment distilled into an entire game. Each round of every single fight captures the thrill of those final few seconds in a tightly-contested bout; the moment that entices newcomers to the genre and sends diehard fans into mass hysteria. And it’s all accomplished with only two buttons.

What started out as a simple concept featuring two near-mechanically identical characters and a staple move of 2D fighting games, has now evolved to feature a roster of thirteen that surprises with its hidden depth. It’s odd to say that a game with only two buttons has any intricacy, but therein lies Divekick’s beauty. With one button to jump and one to kick it’s easily accessible for newcomers to the genre. Rounds are a quick twenty seconds and each fight’s nine possible rounds will end after one single hit. It’s the fighting game condensed to its purest form, sans any barrier to entry and welcoming to those dumbfounded and put off by the commitment required to learn the inner workings of the genres best. It’s a test of reads and reactions, of tactically positioning yourself based on your character’s idiosyncrasies and those of your opponent.

You simply jump and divekick, launching through the air to knock your opponent down in their stride.The characters of Dive and Kick showcase this concept at its base level, adopting the roles of Ken and Ryu (even if they are parodies of Yun and Yang) in Divekick’s outlandish universe with the most easy-to-grasp attacks. Positioning is determined by how high you jump and the angle of your kick. Press the kick button when your feet are on the ground and you hop backwards; kick enough and your super meter fills, how you use it depends on your fighter selection. These are simple systems and mechanics that welcome the uninitiated, removing the need to mesmerise button combos. Anyone can pick up Divekick and immediately start having fun, and it’s certainly at its best when played with friends, either locally or online.

However, there is an ever present complexity underpinning this apparent simplicity. Venture away from Dive and Kick and you’ll encounter characters with variations on the simple divekick. The Baz, for example, doesn’t defeat his opponents with his kick but with a trail of lightning that follows it. He can also pause mid-air and alter the angle of his kick, making him very effective if you can adjust to the peculiar way he deals damage. Other characters, like Jefailey, change from round to round. With each win his head begins to grow as his ego inflates, allowing you to jump higher while subsequently increasing the likelihood of suffering a critical headshot that leaves you concussed in the next round, drastically reducing the height of your jumps and the speed of your kicks. Dr Shoals, on the other hand, can perform a trajectory altering kick during her initial attack.

Each of Divekick’s thirteen characters adopt their own unique move lists, terrifically setting them apart from one another. That philosophy continues as you begin to experiment with each fighter’s singular special moves. As you build up the super meter via kicking you can either exert it by using Kick Factor (a parody of Marvel vs Capcom 3’s X-Factor that speeds up your character for a limited time) or by using your special moves. Each character has a ground move and an air move that can be activated by pressing both buttons at once provided you have enough meter. These range from the ability to temporarily float in the air to avoid dangerous situations or to set-up divekicks of your own, to a shoryuken-style Upkick and a handy duck. Though each character shares the same two buttons it quickly becomes apparent how diverse they each are, drawing an improbable amount of depth out of its simple control scheme.

Of course, this welcome complexity does contradict the notion that Divekick is incredibly easy to pick-up-and-play for newcomers to the fighting genre. There’s certainly an amount of explanation required whenever someone new picks a different character and wants to learn their many quirks, but Divekick handily subsides this somewhat with a story mode for each fighter. The AI is a tad on the easy side but these fights offer up a way to learn each character’s move list whilst unearthing their back stories via a handful of short motion comics.

Once you begin to play competitively against other people Divekick’s appeal is at its most discernible. Whether you’re playing locally with friends for a laugh or displaying your high-level skills in a ranked match, Divekick’s mechanics and use of basic fighting game concepts translate well to any environment. Some may write it off because of its simplistic control scheme and visual style but they would be missing the point. It may have slightly deviated from its original design to welcome the uninitiated to the genre – the many, many knowing references reveal a game that’s meant for the fighting game community more than anyone else – but the added depth proves welcome, even if it requires a little more understanding. Divekick is still all about that one moment, there’s just a little more nuance along the way.

reviewText:
The One True Game:

Originally made as a joke game with only two characters for a fighting game tournament, Divekick is a very unique 1-on-1 fighting game by Iron Galaxy Studios.

What do I mean with unique? Well, it only has two buttons. Yes, you read that correctly, just two. No directional inputs, no macros, none of that. Just a button to jump (Dive) and a button to descend with a kick (Kick). You can also jump backwards if you press kick You even navigate the game menus just by using those two buttons as well. This game is just about diving and kicking, and every hit is an instant K.O. Divekicks, for those who never played fighting games, are a mechanic that some characters have in some already established fighting game franchises, and are usually seen as a great technique for any character who possesses them.

Despite having very simple gameplay mechanics, the game is surprisingly deep and varied, and being just a two button fighter, anyone can get into it easily. Each of the 13 characters, who are parodies of other fighting game characters and personalities from the FGC (Fighting Game Community), has its own jump height and kicking speed and angle. Like most fighting games nowadays, it also has a meter, which can be used in different ways. Each character has a different Ground ability and an Air ability, activated by pressing both buttons in ground and air respectively. Some abilities can even work together, like Kung Pao's Ground ability, which creates a sort of dimensional crack above herself, which she can then use to teleport through using her Air ability. Each ability's cost depends on the character as well, which ends up adding even more variety to this game. Also, when you fill up your meter, Kick Factor automatically activates (if you ever played Marvel vs. Capcom 3, this mechanic might sound familiar to you). Kick Factor basically powers up your character's diving and kicking for a limited period of time. And to add even more variety, before every match you must choose one of 4 gems (a parody of Street Fighter X Tekken's gems), which powers up by 10% either your Dive, your Kick, your Meter gain, or a 30% boost for all 3 of them with the painful cost of beginning the game with 4 rounds already lost.

Like I mentioned before, every hit is a one hit K.O. (each hit does 1 BILLION DAMAGE), so each match is a first to 5 20-second rounds in order for matches to have some length. It has a very creative way to solve timeouts, making a red vertical line appear at a random point in the stage, and when time runs out, the character who is closer to the line wins the round. It has a simple story mode, with a final boss that can be unforgiving even in normal difficulties. Unfortunately I can't comment on the online, but it uses GGPO, so netcode must be good. Being from where I am, finding an opponent in ranked matches has been impossible for me so far XD.

Voice acting is one of the things that I think is unimpressive about this game. I know this isn't a major detail, but some characters' voices are not cool, and can sometimes feel even a bit annoying. Also, if you do not belong to the FGC, you probably won't understand most of the jokes in this game, but maybe that's not a bad thing. If anything, curiosity in those jokes might want you to get into the FGC. I also feel that there's too much FGC-related stuff going on in this game. Some of it is a bit unnecessary in my opinion. All in all, I think this game does not excel in the comedy department. Music is decent as well. Not too complicated tracks for a not too complicated game is a perfect fit the way I see it.

---------------------------------------------------------------

To sum up, Divekick is a unique and very interesting take on the fighting genre, one where anyone can get in and have fun at any moment, while also being a big (sometimes too big) love letter to the FGC. It's no Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat, but the depth and variety hidden within its seemingly simple gameplay might surprise you. And with its very low cost, it's a game that can't be missed.

A fighting game that can cater to basically any kind of gamer, in one way or another, is an amazing accomplishment.

This is a fighting game for everyone.

ood fighting games boil down to position and timing, and Divekick gave me exquisite control over both through an intuitive two-button interface. It subverts expectations by whittling the notoriously complex movesets of the fighting genre down to two simple maneuvers: diving and kicking. The result is engaging – after only a few rounds of combat, I was able to feint, dodge, and fake out my opponent with gratifying precision. Peel away the colorful artwork, and Divekick closely resembles the best of classic arcade fighter design philosophy. The goals and interface are instantly comprehensible, bouts are quick,

A diverse cast of characters infuse Divekick with a variety of special abilities without overly complicating matters. I found something to appreciate in every one of the 13 warriors, but I kept coming back to Uncle Sensei, a cartwheeling hippie wearing boots on his hands. The nearly horizontal angle of his full-body Divekick extension leaves him vulnerable, but it frequently beguiled my opponents, creating an intriguing risk vs. reward proposition.
Divekick’s humor varies between cute and bizarre, and occasionally it goes too far. There are gobs of in-jokes about fighting-game tournament culture, staples, and tropes, as well as less obscure comedic one-liners. Some of the visual gags are quite funny – I laughed out loud the first time I watched one of the fighters writing notes on her clipboard while divekicking through the air, immediately before her foot impacted on my face.
Less successful is the tongue-in-cheek commentary on racial prejudice. Mr. N’s announcement that “I don’t hug white girls” might make sense to folks familiar with personalities in the fighting-game circuit, but stripped of context it just comes across as unsettling and offensive. The ill-advised naming of Asian martial artist Kung Pao also strikes a distasteful chord.
The Vita version has a remarkable competitive two-player mode. My first local Divekick match took place in an IGN hallway on a single handheld, where I held half of the Vita and my opponent held the other half. I expected the layout to be awkward, but was pleasantly surprised to find it quite ergonomic. I could easily envision two friends on a train or kids sharing the back seat on a road trip going at it. It can, of course, also be played online, and my experiences on PS3, Vita, and PC were nearly free of latency.


THE VERDICT

Divekick is a deep, refreshingly approachable tournament fighter. The unusual control configuration is no gimmick, but rather a functional design choice that helps tear down the barrier of entry for players intimidated by combo breakers and juggling. It is unfortunate that there’s not a better single-player mode, and more unfortunate that Divekick’s cultural insensitivity can be downright cringe-worthy, but it’s still a successful experiment in simplified fighting.

reviewText:
Dive kick is quite simply one of the most fun and interesting games I have played this year and while for the most part I would love to leave it there I just cannot do so. Dive kick is one of those games that appears once every so often out of the blue and is possibly one of the fun and simplest games I have ever ha the joy of playing in my lifetime. The games developers Iron Galaxy studios are well known for their ports of popular gaming franchises to consoles and PC's including the soon to be port of Borderlands 2 for the PS Vita and developing the lacklustre game 'Wreckateer' for the Xbox 360s arcade.

Dive kick is a fighting game to its core with the simple premise of knocking out an opponent with a twist-- you must jump into the air and hurl yourself towards the opponent to DIVEKICK them to win the match using just two buttons for jumping into the air and dive kicking your opponent. Rounds end quite quickly with a typical match lasting between 2-5 minutes long and for the most part it becomes a frantic battle to try and stay as high in the air compared to your opponent in hopes of getting them off their guard, that is not to say however that Dive Kick has no skill involved. I found myself trying to outsmart my opponent by various different tactics such as; standing still and waiting the psyche out my opponent, however in the air, going for make and break by instantly jumping and diving for a quick kill and more.

Before you start a match you are introduced to a variety of characters each with their own stories and unique abilities which allow for higher jumps, faster kicks and in some cases even slight hovers. After the characters and skins have been chosen you are then given a new option to choose a gem which act as the games help for your character... most of the time. There are some gems that are there purely for either fun or a means to show off! I am talking of course about the YOLO gem, a gem which gives the opposite player a 4 round lead only needing to dive kick the opponent once to win. I found myself most of the time choosing YOLO gem to challenge myself, to see if it was possible to actually win but I could never succeed.

My first impressions of DiveKick were quite literally this: What? I can play a fighting game without learning ridiculously hard to pull of combos, anyone can jump into it and know exactly what they need to do to win and it's fun to play? Where do i sign up!? Because that is what it really is, a game which anyone can play without having any prior knowledge of what the game is about or what they need to do. It is a game that brings people together for a forgotten sense of whimsical enjoyment and fun that seems lost in many fighting games lately and is a game which relies on playing tactically and biding your time and not knowing more than the other person and being able to pull off a move without your opponent screaming 'how did you do that?! that's a clear advantage!'

Sadly however the game is not as much fun by yourself and should be primarily played with other people either locally or online. That is, if you can connect to someone to play with in the first place. I found myself waiting for long periods of time to finally find a person to play against during the launch week of the game and ended up just turning the game off all together, unplugging my console and going over to a friend's house to play it with them instead.

It must be stated however that Dive Kick is fun, there is no question about it. It's a game that brings together the enjoyment of playing together with friends and is a simple idea done right. Dive kick should be a title picked up by everyone and anyone who has a PC or PS3/Vita. Dive kick gets my sphere score of a 8/10 for its sheer replay-ability, hilarious characters and great system. Kudos Iron Galaxy Studios and the team behind Dive kick! I am here hoping for DLC/Dive Kick 2!

reviewText:
I have a bit of mixed feelings for Divekick. It's exactly what I predicted it would feel like gameplay-wise. Originally I bought this as a gift for a friend on the day it came out. I think the price was overkill. But it really depends on some factors:

- You like parodies made on Mortal Kombat.

- You're looking for comedy based on ethnocentrism or prejudice.

- You're not looking for cool combos. Just K.O's.

Overall I personally don't think the game is bad. Worth the daily deal of $2.50? Maybe. Depends on the factors I mentioned above. Otherwise you could do away without it.

In just under 1 hr you'll mostly see everything there is to know about this game. And from there on you can either keep playing it, or never play it again.

One thing I sometimes like to note about games is the credits. I counted about 50+ people that designed this game. This is too much for an Indie company imho. After all, the more complex Doom 3 was made by roughly the same amount of people before 2005. Divekick is the type of game that strikes me as a 5 man job. I'm fairly certain I've seen just as interesting web-based flash plugin fighter games.

The mechanics is sort of interesting. Each character seems to differ only by speed or boost to the dive (forwards/backwards) and the kick. I also feel that there is some weird collision system happening based on the dimensions of the characters. But overall it seems like you tend to get the most success of a K.O by allowing the enemy to attack first. There are special moves, however I ultimately still believe the many variations are caused by a change in speed.

For example, if you have a character that kicks at medium speed, you might notice that a character that drifts slowly may be more deadly as they tend to perform more of a flying kick rather than a divekick. But if you have a character that divekicks too fast, you may easily K.O someone that seems to be doing a slow-mo flying kick.

Although the music is sort of transparent to me. It's reminiscent to I guess classic games like Double Dragon and Streets of Rage.

As a tiny quarrel: Initially I thought the main menu wasn't very intuitive. After a minute I get it. But it still feels bad navigating thereafter. I quote from Albert Einstein, Make everything as simple as possible
date: but not simpler." That certainly applies to the main menu in terms of user-friendliness.\n\nIt seems to be that a large portion of this game has a lot to do with online multiplayer. DiveKick is a joke, a joke meant for a very niche set of gamers, a set i would consider myself a part of, the Fighting Game Community.

Unfortunately its a joke that doesnt hold up, the premise is fantastic, remove the barrier for entry (complex button inputs and mechanic understanding) and make a fighting game entirely about the meta game, the understanding of your oponent, trying to predict their moves and then setting up traps for them to spring, this is encredibly satisfying or it would if about half the roster werent rather broken and somewhat unbalanced, there are certain match ups that are always going to benefit one character over the other, S=Kill (a parody of seth killian an ex capcom community manager) and the baz (a character joke from two best friends play i do believe) are really rather broken and somewhat overpowered

Divekick is at its best when being played purely with the characters Dive and Kick, this games Ryu and Ken except these guys are west philadelphia born and raised. The story and characters are great if you get the jokes, but theyre just jokes that after theyre initial chuckle value dont hold up much, and characters like Mr. N and Jefailey are really niche paradies of major people involved within the FGC not every person interested in fighting games are gonna understand those jokes, i chuckled at jebaileys head growing bigger with each win but i had to google the backstory to Mr. N just so i wouldnt feel like i was missing the joke,

not all the joke characters are broken wolvereine and Dr Shoals are pretty awesome and the idea of stripping a fighting game down to its purest form is interesting but this just about misses the mark unfortunately.

while i love that a game like this exists, the type of people who this game is really intended for probably already know enough about it to decide whether they intend to purchase it, and personally it isnt worth the full asking price, i got this on offer using money made from trading card sales but the idea of dropping cash on this, especially full price would have left me feeling very ripped off, the art work and animation quality are pretty poor as is the music, no great tunes here but obviously these arent as important as the gameplay, DiveKick is best played locally or with friends, who already play fighting games, and who stick to the unbroken characters, theres fun to be had here but theres a lot of problems too.

Ive had some collision detection issues with this, more than once ive sailed right through someone stomach and its not counted as a hit and looking online im not alone with this,

if you are interested in this game, just be prepared for a lot of faults and kinda amateur ish quality, even then dont pay full price for this, to be honest its got Humble Bundle written all over it so just be patient and im sure itll turn up for a fair price at somepoint, a great idea that i can only recommend to very few people and for this reason it doesnt get my recommendation however i will say the GGPO net code is freaking superb no lag problems for me so far.

all in all, buy with caution

Trying this game out on a whim, I was won over almost instantly. I don't think I've ever laughed as hard playing a fighting game as I have playing Divekick. Its simplistic input design masks a plethora of fun. Everything from funny and interesting references of fighting games and the FGC to the realization of how silly it is to be so salty over the fact that you got beat by Jefailey even though you were playing the Baz. So I'll reiterate - if you like fighting games, or even if you think you might like fighting games, pick this game up. Pick it up for yourself, and get a couple copies for your friends too, because just like every other fighting game, it's more fun with friends!

reviewText: As a guy who enjoys kickass fighting games, Divekick is a pretty enjoyable kickass fighting game. The two button gameplay works well - it gives players only the bare minimum to move, attack, and defend, but that's all any player needs. As a result, the game gets to the meat of what fighting games are all about - reading your opponent and outplaying them. There's no elaborate combo system or pretzel motions to learn, so players can learn to play the game more quickly instead of just playing their character (though character matchups certainly have their importance). And because of the 1-hit KO system, anyone can be a threat - this isn't Marvel where a skilled player can steamroll a newbie with his eyes closed just because he knows touch of death combos by muscle memory. Every opponent demands caution and strategy, which keeps the game from getting dull (though it does get exhausting). The art is pretty bad, and the story mode isn't as ridiculous as it ought to be, but Divekick is about divekicking people in the face, and god damn does it succeed at doing that.\n\nAnd don't be that guy who thinks only Street Fighter clones are allowed into the hallowed halls of the Fighting Game Genre. That guy sucks at fighters. Play Divekick.

reviewText:
Divekick is how people solve legal disputes in the dystopian future.

It's also a loving satire of the fighting game community. And as much as Divekick hilariously parodies fighting games, it does more with its stripped-down mechanics than some full-fledged competitive fighters do with theirs. Divekick isn't the game to abandon the classics of the genre for; rather, its simplified mechanics remind us why we loved them, and how to continue to love them. We didn't start playing fighters for 500-hit 0-death air combos and irritating comeback mechanics. We came for decisive action, heated mindgames, and a healthy dose of hype.

Divekick, along with the more traditional but equally solid Skullgirls, provides tight mechanics, clear design, and a unique and imaginative experience to be treasured by fighting game veterans and newcomers alike.

reviewText:
If you're looking for great singleplayer or expansive online play, look elsewhere.

If you are, instead, looking for something to play with a group of friends, or at parties, it's great for some laughs. The rounds are short enough to cycle losers out, and new challengers in, which keeps everyone involved in a two-player game pretty nicely.

The mechanics of the game are as simple as they can get: You dive (jump) and you kick. There are also two specials (One in the air, one on the ground) which can be activated by hitting both buttons at once. If you get hit, you lose. OHKO. But there is a surprising amount of depth to the play: One character teleports before every move, making him close to unreadable. Another one can go invisible, and a third can kick you through a tear in reality. And on top of this, every character has different jump heights, kick angles, and some can change these numbers in-game. It certainly helps to know your opponent, just as in any standard fighting game.

But again, this is definitely best if you have friends close by that you can play with: It shines in local multiplayer.

reviewText:
A brilliant, fun and humerous concept, that is so simple to play, but is let down hugely by the parts before and after the actual game itself.

'However', the fast pace fun is broken so much by inbetween pauses with some randon and extremely annoying 'Fraud Detection' thing, that doesn't make any sense to me and the having to hear the same thing over and over on each round is seriously off putting. It has actually stopped me from playing it already.

The animation is fluid and drawn well, just not varied enough for this type of game.

The music is just plain boring and better turned off. I can see what they are trying to mimic, but it's been done badly and made it more annoying than anything.

The included characters are interesting enough, but really needs more variations and 'more' weirdness I feel.

I've yet to play 'anyone' on-line as it simply never connects, no matter what I choose (ranked or unranked) and just sits in lobby screen suggesting it's searching, but does nothing for ages.

The controls work really well and are simply based on two buttons/keys only, and can be configured for one or two players using any keyboard (solo or shared on one keyboard like in the good old days) and will also happily use a game pad too (I tested a wireless Xbox controller which was fine).

You get the usual options to change your screen setting; resolution, full screen and graphical capabilities, and also audio levels.

The game works perfectly in Steam's Big Picture mode and never failed or crashed for me.

It's a shame that the game has these annoying pauses and pointless 'Fraud' thingy between every fight and needs to be changed, speeded up or just removed.

I 'would' highly recommend this game, but would have to go with 'Recommended with caution' because of the above faults.

reviewText:
My favorite genre is fighting games, no series is alike, each with their own mechanics, gimmicks and unique cast of characters. Divekick takes a unique turn on the genre by being a 'gag fighting game' in a sense. Divekick take the traditional fighting game mechanics and strips it down to the basics: Mind-games, pressure, and positioning.

Divekick as all fighting games has it own gimmick which is that it is a simple, basic, striped down fighting game. Divekick is a 2 button fighter composed of 'best of 9' matches, each round is sudden death (One hit KO) and last 20 seconds.

Divekick is a gag fighter but it is also a really good fighting game, its simplist style is a great way for newcomers to learn the genre and to learn about basic mechanic in fighters such as mind-games, pressuring, positioning, and match-ups but it as simple as this game is, it also offer a great degree of high level play. Experts of the genre can still have a great time with this game and still have feeling of high leveled, competitive gameplay.

Whether you're a newcomer to the genre or a veteran, this is a great to pick up. It's is not meant to be taken as a serious game but even then there is still that bit of high leveled play that veterans like and newcomers can come to like.

reviewText:
My favorite genre is fighting games, no series is alike, each with their own mechanics, gimmicks and unique cast of characters. Divekick takes a unique turn on the genre by being a 'gag fighting game' in a sense. Divekick take the traditional fighting game mechanics and strips it down to the basics: Mind-games, pressure, and positioning.

Divekick as all fighting games has it own gimmick which is that it is a simple, basic, striped down fighting game. Divekick is a 2 button fighter composed of 'best of 9' matches, each round is sudden death (One hit KO) and last 20 seconds.

Divekick is a gag fighter but it is also a really good fighting game, its simplist style is a great way for newcomers to learn the genre and to learn about basic mechanic in fighters such as mind-games, pressuring, positioning, and match-ups but it as simple as this game is, it also offer a great degree of high level play. Experts of the genre can still have a great time with this game and still have feeling of high leveled, competitive gameplay.

Whether you're a newcomer to the genre or a veteran, this is a great to pick up. It's is not meant to be taken as a serious game but even then there is still that bit of high leveled play that veterans like and newcomers can come to like.

reviewText: Divekick is that parody fighting game you may have heard about that only uses two buttons. Despite the game's lack of input options (seeing as there are only two buttons) it is more than just dive and kick, rinse and repeat. If you want to come out on top, you will have to out-smart your opponent while avoiding falling pray to their own mind games. Seeing as the first one to get hit loses, one mistaken can lose you a round and repeated mistakes will surely end in defeat.\nBeing the parody fighting game that Divekick is, the game comes with many references and jokes originating from the fighting game community that appear all over the game. As someone who has never played many fighting games, I didn't get most of the references, but a little research  or a friend versed in said community can help to clear a few things up.\nUltimately, Divekick is a funny, enjoyable and straightforward game that catters to all gamers of all skill levels. The biggest complaint about the game is that it can feel a little short lived, especially since the community has begun to dwindle and the story mode will only last you so long. This can be a problem for those with hurting wallets looking for the most bag for your buck, but playing with friends is always a blast. $10 might seem a little steep for some, but it's definetly worth getting on sale if you've had any interst in the game.

reviewText: Divekick is a really interesting concept that almost lives up to it's full potential. The biggest problem with fighting games tends to be the time investment it takes to learn a character, from their moveset to their matchups to actial execution of combos. Divekick removes most of that, mapping everything to two buttons. This moves most of the focus to the mindgame portion of fighting games, which is really what makes them interesting. My biggest problem with Divekick is that the characters are just varied enough that it serves to undermine the premise. You could stick with playing Dive or Kick, who are pretty simple, but what if you didn't know that Jefailey charges his dropkick? This makes the investment needed to truly enjoy this game clash a bit with the underlying simplicity. All in all, Divekick still executes really well what it set out to do, with some minor issues.

reviewText:
I am not a fighting game player.

That being said Divekick is the best fighting game I have ever played. Sure I really liked stuff like Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat, and the like... But Divekick is the first time I ever felt like I could compete legitimately.

The Lang Zone is in full effect here with a brilliantly minimalist design. All characters have a million health and every attack does four million damage. There are two buttons. You jump, and then you kick. The brilliance of this design is that it is so simple yet there is depth in the way each character jumps, how each one kicks, and how their supers behave. Even the super moves are brilliantly simple, being activated simply by hitting both buttons at once and changing depending on whether you are on the ground or in the air.

I watched this game developed from the ground up thanks to the beautiful romance between Dave Lang and the GB crew and I'm so happy I saw it all the way through. I might not play it nearly as much as I should but if you want a fun, fast, popcorn-like fighting game nothing does it better than Divekick.

Get bopped, son.

reviewText:
On the surface, Divekick is not much of anything - It's a fighting game built on the fundimental premise of jumping and kicking, mixed with humor that really only works on the fighting game community. However, this isn't a game to buy for what it is on the surface.

Underneath the simplistic and honestly lackluster facade is the biggest crash course in fighting game fundimentals you'll ever experience. If you just mash buttons and divekick randomly, you are going to get absoultely murdered. Spacing and mindgames are everything. You need to trick your opponent into making a mistake, and you need to make sure you maintain control of the situation.

Overall, Divekick isn't a good game because of what it is, but because of what it does. It teaches you to play mind games with opponents. It teaches you the importance of making your attacks safe, and above all else, it teaches you the fundimentals of fighting games.

Now, it's time for the breakdown... Oh dear...

Graphics: Love the resolution and the framerate. Hate the jerky animations.
Sound: Nothing to mention.
Story: Fighting games don't lend themselves to storywriting and Divekick is no exception.
Gameplay: Overly simple but at the same time extremely deep.

Recommended for: People who are serious about fighting games.
Not recommended for: People who aren't serious about fighting games.

Bottom line: A fighting game that strips the whole concept of fighting games to their bare minimum, removing the flash and showyness but keeping the fundimentals intact.

reviewText:
Nearly everyone has played a fighting game, be it Mortal Kombat, Street Fighter, Tekken, Dead or Alive, at least one of them. Some people play one and dedicate hours into learning movesets, combos, counters, specials; all kinds of complex, frustrating game mechanics. Others just pick a fighter and find a move that they can beat others with reliably. Still others try one and never play again, put down by the large list of things to learn in order to play.

With Divekick, all that complex crap is thrown out the window into moving traffic at rush hour. Divekick reduces the core of the fighting genre down to two measly buttons. I don't mean two attack buttons and a d-pad, I mean nothing but two buttons for EVERYTHING: menus, attacking, movement, everything (except pause, but that's besides the point).

'You must be joking, ' I hear you thinking, 'that sounds like a crappy mobile game, not a hardcore fighter!' Well, technically, it IS a joke, more of a parody really. Divekick is a jab at the fighting game genre, it's filled with in-jokes and references to prominent characters and people that mostly only hardcore fighter enthusiasts would understand.
